required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Cytokines Associated With Cord Blood Cell Therapy for Neonatal Encephalopathy
clinical_study.official_title: A Study to Determine if Autologous Umbilical Cord Blood Cell Therapy Alters Serum Levels of Cytokines and Trophic Factors in Neonatal Encephalopathy

collaborator.agency: National Center for Child Health and Development, Japan

brief_summary.textblock: This is a observational study to assess the effects of and to explore the mechanisms of autologous umbilical cord blood cell therapy for neonatal encephalopathy by way of measuring serum cytokines.

detailed_description.textblock: The effects and mechanisms of umbilical cord blood cell therapy for perinatal brain injury are not well understood. This is a multicenter study to measure serum levels of inflammatory cytokines and trophic factors associated with perinatal brain injury and repair in term gestation newborns with neonatal encephalopathy (hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy). This study proceeds along with the study "Autologous cord blood cell therapy for neonatal encephalopathy (ClinicalTrials.gov identifier: NCT02256618)". Blood samples are obtained before the first cell infusion, and subsequently 2h, 24h, 48h, and 7 days after the first cell infusion. Blood samples are obtained in the same manner from newborns with neonatal encephalopathy who are not receiving the cell therapy.

primary_outcome.measure: Changes in serum levels of cytokines and trophic factors
primary_outcome.time_frame: From birth up to 10 days of age

secondary_outcome.measure: Association with neuroimaging and neurodevelopmental functional outcome
secondary_outcome.description: Neuroimaging at 12 months of age and neurodevelopmental function at 18 months of age will be assessed whether they are associated with serum levels of cytokines and trophic factors during the early neonatal period.

arm_group.description: Infants with encephalopathy who receive autologous umbilical cord blood cell therapy along with therapeutic hypothermia.
Infants with encephalopathy who receive therapeutic hypothermia only.

intervention.description: The neonates receive their own non-cryopreserved volume- and red blood cell-reduced cord blood cells. The cord blood cells are divided into 3 doses and intravenously infused at 12-24, 36-48, and 60-72 hours after the birth.

study_pop.textblock: Infants with encephalopathy who meet the inclusion criteria of therapeutic hypothermia, either those who receive the cell therapy or those who do not.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
Infants are eligible if they meet all the following inclusion criteria except 4.
1. ≥36 weeks gestation
2. Either a 10-minute Apgar score ≤5, continued need for resuscitation for at least 10 minutes, or severe acidosis, defined as pH <7.0 or base deficit ≥16 mmol/L in a sample of umbilical cord blood or any blood during the first hour after birth
3. Moderate to severe encephalopathy (Sarnat II to III)
4. A moderately or severely abnormal background amplitude-integrated EEG (aEEG) voltage, or seizures identified by aEEG, if monitored
5. Up to 24 hours of age
6. A person with parental authority must have consented for the study.
Exclusion Criteria:
1. Known major congenital anomalies, such as chromosomal anomalies, heart diseases
2. Major intracranial hemorrhage identified by brain ultrasonography or computed tomography
3. Severe growth restriction, with birth-weight less than 1800 g
4. Severe infectious disease, such as sepsis
5. Infants judged critically ill and unlikely to benefit from neonatal intensive care including hypothermia by the attending neonatologist

overall_official.affiliation: Osaka City University Graduate School of Medicine
